keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after a family alerted authorities that he had planned to shoot up the airport on a social media livestream.
Cagle was seen arriving at the airport in a Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal and had a high interest in the TSA security checkpoint.
Police discovered an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his truck, confirming the threat.
He was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Cagle had previously posted on Facebook that he was schizophrenic and was taking medication, and a friend reported concerns about his mental health.
The arrest was credited to a tip from his family, which led to early intervention and prevention of a potential mass shooting.
Atlanta Police and federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which he was legally unable to possess.
The incident is seen as a success in preventing a tragedy due to community vigilance and timely information sharing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, Billy Joe Cagle, was arrested at the world’s busiest airport, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, after a family alerted police that he had streamed on social media a plan to 'shoot it up' at the facility. Authorities found an AR-15 rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle, who had previously posted on Facebook about being schizophrenic, was charged with multiple felonies including terroristic threats and unlawful firearm possession. A tip from family members, including a friend named Nick Roberts who had expressed concern about Cagle’s mental health, led to the timely intervention that averted a potential mass shooting. The incident is being hailed as a success due to early detection, community vigilance, and cooperation between local and federal law enforcement, with officials like Chief Darin Schierbaum and Mayor Andre Dickens publicly thanking the community for preventing tragedy.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Social Media Threat to Shoot Up Facility
